column2: Scott Gottlieb: What's the point of banning travel from India now?
column5: There must be some scientific reason why heâ€™s puzzled about this while normies like you and me arenâ€™t but if there is he doesnâ€™t offer it in the clip. Watch then read on. Former FDA commissioner on India travel ban: â€œIâ€™m not sure what weâ€™re hoping to accomplishâ€ @ScottGottliebMD tells @jdickerson.  He says that the variant that has emerged there is likely already in the US. pic.twitter.com/htmIGMxsos â€” Face The Nation (@FaceTheNation) May 2 2021  Indiaâ€™s â€œdouble mutantâ€ variant is already here he notes. So what are we achieving by preventing travel from India? Isnâ€™t the answer â€¦ â€œweâ€™re slowing the spread of that variantâ€? Imagine you walk into a forest light five matches and drop them on the ground at random spots. In all likelihood all five matches will burn out without starting a forest fire. Now imagine doing the same thing with 500 matches. The odds of a big blaze rise. If we have travelers from India carrying the â€œdouble mutantâ€ arriving in the U.S. each day and dispersing throughout the country the odds grow that one of them will end up in a community with a high percentage and that the variant will begin spreading rapidly. So we want to limit the number of matches that are dropped even though we know that a certain number are already burning right? What am I missing? Heâ€™s right though about ending the travel bans on the UK and I guess China. If we can restrict travel to and from India to minimize community spread here we should also un-restrict it in countries where the virus isnâ€™t spreading aggressively anymore. The UKâ€™s positivity rate is lower than ours is. Gottlieb is looking forward on the India travel ban wondering what future benefit weâ€™ll gain from it. Other doctors are looking backward and asking the question I asked on Friday: Why didnâ€™t Joe Biden and his crack team of COVID warriors impose the ban weeks ago before Indiaâ€™s outbreak became a nuclear reactor of contagion? â€œItâ€™s been clear for more than a month that India is the epicenter of the pandemicâ€ said Dr. Arnold Monto a professor of epidemiology and global health at the University of Michigan. â€œThese restrictions should have been in effect weeks ago.â€ [Professor Lawrence] Gostin said the delay in issuing guidance as well as the four-day break in between the announcement of the restrictions and their implementation made him concerned that the government was falling behind in the race to keep Indiaâ€™s variants from gaining a foothold in the United States where half of adults have gotten at least one dose of the coronavirus vaccine. The lack of clarity on potential quarantine for those following the guidance by returning home too is a source of frustration for public health experts. â€œI do have concernsâ€ Gostin said. â€œAnnouncing the travel restrictions in advance will mean that many more passengers from India will arrive before then some carrying dangerous variants into the U.S. Also there are no clear rules for U.S. citizens who are just as likely to spread variants when they arrive home.â€ Maybe Gottliebâ€™s a fatalist about the Indian variant spreading here because of what he said yesterday about â€œconvergent evolution.â€ The reason the same variants keep popping up in country after country isnâ€™t necessarily because travelers are bringing them in he notes in the clip below. In some cases the same variants may be rising spontaneously in isolated populations because particular mutations have an evolutionary advantage. The British variant spreads more easily than the common coronavirus does for instance so go figure that if the common virus happens to mutate in an infected American in the same way as the British variant it might begin spreading from him to his community and suddenly we have a â€œBritish variantâ€ outbreak here. In that case we should expect to see Indiaâ€™s â€œdouble mutantâ€ pop up eventually whether or not anyoneâ€™s bringing it in from India or not. COVID VARIANTS: Former FDA commissioner @ScottGottliebMD says that COVID-19 variants that have emerged in other corners of the world are likely naturally occurring here in the US noting that aggressive vaccination in the US is likely why they havenâ€™t taken a foothold. pic.twitter.com/qrxGxvFHmg â€” Face The Nation (@FaceTheNation) May 2 2021  Makes sense â€” except again *delaying* the spread of variants by limiting travel is useful no? Even if weâ€™re destined to see the Indian variant emerge here it matters a lot whether it emerges when 50 percent of Americans are still unvaccinated versus when only 20 percent are. The Indian variant isnâ€™t the one to worry about right now though. This afternoon Seattle scientist Trevor Bedford flagged the fact that the Brazilian variant P.1 has been picking up steam lately in the United States.  Given that P.1 frequency is growing rapidly but overall cases are generally falling the question becomes are vaccines and other control measures enough to curb spread of P.1 in absolute case counts? 6/13 â€” Trevor Bedford (@trvrb) May 3 2021  However plotting partitioned case counts on a log-scale clearly shows the continued growth in absolute case counts of P.1. 8/13 pic.twitter.com/raMmZ66aeu â€” Trevor Bedford (@trvrb) May 3 2021  A geneticist whoâ€™s studying COVID echoed Bedford noting that heâ€™s seeing P.1 more frequently lately too. Note the increase in green bars lately in the graph. Great thread from @trvrb on growth of P.1 in the US.  We can see it in @my_helix data. See this dashboard: https://t.co/dJv1ItkVtS  In all US we see ~20% of non-SGTF tests that are P.1 & ğŸ“ˆ. https://t.co/qH30asfRcQ pic.twitter.com/ImrImEGNBh â€” Alexandre Bolze (@alexbolze) May 3 2021  The Brazilian variant is notorious for its apparent ability to reinfect some people whoâ€™ve already had COVID and recovered from it. The good news is that early lab tests suggest that Pfizerâ€™s vaccine works against P.1. The bad news is that it might not be quite as effective as it is against the common virus; one scientist expects that if we end up getting a newly designed booster shot in the fall itâ€™ll target the Brazilian or South African variants because vaccinated people need a bit of extra protection from those strains. The bottom line is clear though: If youâ€™re on the fence about being vaxxed nowâ€™s the time to do it before P.1 runs wild. Thatâ€™s the variant that brought Brazil to its knees. We probably have too many people vaccinated already to suffer a major outbreak here but those who are unvaccinated are still susceptible to bad outcomes. Donâ€™t wait.
